description:
a database of RNA splice junctions in human normal and cancerous tissues.

RNA splicing is an essential step of RNA processing for multi-exon genes, in which introns are removed from a newly synthesized precursor RNA producing mature RNAs containing splice junctions. RJunBase is a database for three kinds of RNA splice junctions derived from RNA-seq datasets of different normal and cancerous tissues.
name: RJunBase

metadata.abstract: Â© 2021 The Author(s) 2020. Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of Nucleic Acids Research.Splicing is an essential step of RNA processing for multi-exon genes, in which introns are removed from a precursor RNA, thereby producing mature RNAs containing splice junctions. Here, we develope the RJunBase (www.RJunBase.org), a web-accessible database of three types of RNA splice junctions (linear, back-splice, and fusion junctions) that are derived from RNA-seq data of non-cancerous and cancerous tissues. The RJunBase aims to integrate and characterize all RNA splice junctions of both healthy or pathological human cells and tissues. This new database facilitates the visualization of the gene-level splicing pattern and the junction-level expression profile, as well as the demonstration of unannotated and tumor-specific junctions. The first release of RJunBase contains 682 017 linear junctions, 225 949 back-splice junctions and 34 733 fusion junctions across 18 084 non-cancerous and 11 540 cancerous samples. RJunBase can aid researchers in discovering new splicing-associated targets and provide insights into the identification and assessment of potential neoepitopes for cancer treatment.
metadata.title: RJunBase: A database of RNA splice junctions in human normal and cancerous tissues
